articles.headline: 2 Banks to Settle Case for $417 Million
articles.snippet: JPMorgan agreed to pay $296.9 million to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the handling of subprime mortgages, and Credit Suisse agreed to pay $120 million.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan agreed to pay $296.9 million to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the handling of subprime mortgages, and Credit Suisse agreed to pay $120 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase and Credit Suisse agreed to settlements with the Securities and Exchange Commission totaling $417 million over their packaging and sale of troubled mortgage securities to investors, the agency said Friday. The settlements are the latest major penalties extracted by the agency in a broad-reaching investigation into how Wall Street firms bundled mortgages into complex investments in the run-up to the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Mistaken Lull, Simple Errand, Death in Gaza
articles.snippet: Believing a cease-fire was in effect for the visit of Egypt’s prime minister, a man left his home to buy cooking gas and was killed in a blast.
articles.abstract: Believing a cease-fire was in effect for the visit of Egypt’s prime minister, a man left his home to buy cooking gas and was killed in a blast.
articles.lead_paragraph: JABALIYA, Gaza Strip — The Abu Wardah family woke up on Friday morning to word that a hudna — Arabic for cease-fire — had been declared during the three-hour visit of the Egyptian prime minister to this embattled territory.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Fares Akram

articles.headline: Another Fumble by the S.E.C. on Fraud
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. dropped charges of securities fraud against an investment manager, a sign that its campaign to hold someone accountable for the mortgage losses at the heart of the financial crisis is in shambles.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. dropped charges of securities fraud against an investment manager, a sign that its campaign to hold someone accountable for the mortgage losses at the heart of the financial crisis is in shambles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward S. Steffelin was at a dinner with clients in Beijing in June 2011 when he got the call from his lawyer, Alex Lipman. The Securities and Exchange Commission was about to charge Mr. Steffelin with securities fraud, blaming him in part for the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Trying to Keep Your E-Mails Secret When the C.I.A. Chief Couldn’t
articles.snippet: Privacy experts say people grossly underestimate how transparent their e-mail accounts are. No matter what you hide there, someone may find out.
articles.abstract: Privacy experts say people grossly underestimate how transparent their e-mail accounts are. No matter what you hide there, someone may find out.
articles.lead_paragraph: If David H. Petraeus couldn’t keep his affair from prying eyes as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, then how is the average American to keep a secret?

articles.headline: After 5 Years of Hiding, a Banker Reappears
articles.snippet: The German hedge fund manager Florian Homm, who disappeared five years ago, resurfaced, vowing to disprove stock-fixing accusations and unveiling a book about his years underground.
articles.abstract: The German hedge fund manager Florian Homm, who disappeared five years ago, resurfaced, vowing to disprove stock-fixing accusations and unveiling a book about his years underground.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Before he disappeared five years ago, Florian Homm seemed to revel in his role as the German hedge fund manager they called “the steamroller.”

articles.headline: Toll Unsettles Los Angeles Motorists Used to ‘Free’ in Freeways
articles.snippet: Los Angeles County’s first toll went into effect last weekend, a jarring experience for motorists used to the “free” in freeways.
articles.abstract: Los Angeles County’s first toll went into effect last weekend, a jarring experience for motorists used to the “free” in freeways.
articles.lead_paragraph: GARDENA, Calif. — They call them freeways for a reason.

articles.headline: As Battlefield Changes, Israel Takes Tougher Approach
articles.snippet: Israel acknowledges that its dangerous world is growing more dangerous. For the country and most of its people, that means not concessions but toughness in pursuit of deterrence.
articles.abstract: Israel acknowledges that its dangerous world is growing more dangerous. For the country and most of its people, that means not concessions but toughness in pursuit of deterrence.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — With rockets landing on the outskirts of Tel Aviv and Jerusalem on Friday and the Egyptian prime minister making a solidarity visit to Gaza, the accelerating conflict between Israel and Hamas — reminiscent in many ways of so many previous battles — has the makings of a new kind of Israeli-Palestinian face-off.

articles.headline: Gulf Coast States at Odds on Penalties for Oil Spill
articles.snippet: Gulf Coast politicians may seek $20 billion or more in civil pollution penalties for the 2010 spill, but negotiations over those penalties could be contentious.
articles.abstract: Gulf Coast politicians may seek $20 billion or more in civil pollution penalties for the 2010 spill, but negotiations over those penalties could be contentious.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — With BP’s agreement on Thursday to plead guilty to 14 criminal charges and pay $4.5 billion in fines and other payments in connection with its 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, Gulf Coast politicians are now eyeing a much bigger potential windfall from the company: $20 billion or more in civil pollution penalties for the spill.

articles.headline: Drug Shortages Persist in U.S., Harming Care
articles.snippet: A drug crisis caused largely by an array of manufacturing problems is leading health care workers to treat patients with less-effective alternative medicines and expired drugs.
articles.abstract: A drug crisis caused largely by an array of manufacturing problems is leading health care workers to treat patients with less-effective alternative medicines and expired drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Paul Davis, the chief of a rural ambulance squad in southern Ohio, was down to his last vial of morphine earlier this fall when a woman with a broken leg needed a ride to the hospital.

articles.headline: Back When a Chocolate Puck Tasted, Guiltily, Like America
articles.snippet: Consumers already knew that not everything is good for you, and this was never truer than with a Twinkie, a Sno Ball or a Ring Ding — the Ding Dong equivalent in the Northeast.
articles.abstract: Consumers already knew that not everything is good for you, and this was never truer than with a Twinkie, a Sno Ball or a Ring Ding — the Ding Dong equivalent in the Northeast.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was a time; admit it. There was a time when, if given a choice between a warm pastry fresh from a baker’s oven and an ageless package of Ring Dings fresh from the 7-Eleven, you would have chosen those Ring Dings. Not even close.

articles.headline: Brand Value Could Entice a Corporate Buyer
articles.snippet: The threat of the demise of the cream-filled cake is evoking nostalgia.
articles.abstract: The threat of the demise of the cream-filled cake is evoking nostalgia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Few would consider Twinkies fine dining. But the threat of their demise is evoking nostalgia, even from foodies who hadn’t deigned to eat them in years.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Israel Broadens Its Bombing in Gaza to Include Government Sites
articles.snippet: Israel expanded its four-day assault on Gaza on Saturday to the civilian political infrastructure, leveling the headquarters of the Hamas prime minister and striking police and security buildings.
articles.abstract: Israel expanded its four-day assault on Gaza on Saturday to the civilian political infrastructure, leveling the headquarters of the Hamas prime minister and striking police and security buildings.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Israel broadened its assault on the Gaza Strip on Saturday from mostly military targets to centers of government infrastructure, obliterating the four-story headquarters of the Hamas prime minister with a barrage of five bombs before dawn.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Isabel Kershner

articles.headline: A Change in Carrots, Without a Stick
articles.snippet: A Louisiana pension fund is suing the Simon Property Group board, contending that shareholders should have voted on the chief executive’s stock award.
articles.abstract: A Louisiana pension fund is suing the Simon Property Group board, contending that shareholders should have voted on the chief executive’s stock award.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHAREHOLDERS get little say on executive pay. Yes, they can get angry. But they can rarely get even.

articles.headline: Privatizing Greece, Slowly but Not Surely
articles.snippet: As Greece redoubles its efforts to cut its debt and stoke its economy, privatization is viewed as a last hope for luring foreign cash. But the effort has been sputtering.
articles.abstract: As Greece redoubles its efforts to cut its debt and stoke its economy, privatization is viewed as a last hope for luring foreign cash. But the effort has been sputtering.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE government inspectors set out from Athens for what they thought was a pristine patch of coastline on the Ionian Sea. Their mission was to determine how much money that sun-kissed shore, owned by the Greek government, might sell for under a sweeping privatization program demanded by the nation’s restive creditors.

articles.headline: Your Online Attention, Bought in an Instant
articles.snippet: In split-second auctions, companies are jockeying for the chance to buy online ads geared to your specific tastes. But consumer advocates see a risk of a computer-generated class system.
articles.abstract: In split-second auctions, companies are jockeying for the chance to buy online ads geared to your specific tastes. But consumer advocates see a risk of a computer-generated class system.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOU can be sold in seconds.

articles.headline: Diplomat on the Rise, Suddenly in Turbulence
articles.snippet: Susan E. Rice, a blunt ambassador said to be a favored candidate for secretary of state, finds herself in the middle of a firestorm over the Benghazi attack.
articles.abstract: Susan E. Rice, a blunt ambassador said to be a favored candidate for secretary of state, finds herself in the middle of a firestorm over the Benghazi attack.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Susan E. Rice was playing stand-in on the morning of Sept. 16 when she appeared on five Sunday news programs, a few days after the deadly attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans.

articles.headline: As Boom Lures App Creators, Tough Part Is Making a Living
articles.snippet: App developers have turned cellphones and tablets into powerful tools, spawning a multibillion-dollar industry but making huge sacrifices in the process.
articles.abstract: App developers have turned cellphones and tablets into powerful tools, spawning a multibillion-dollar industry but making huge sacrifices in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEDALE, Md. — Shawn and Stephanie Grimes spent much of the last two years pursuing their dream of doing research and development for Apple, the world’s most successful corporation.

articles.headline: With Longer Reach, Rockets Bolster Hamas Arsenal
articles.snippet: Israel is focused on arms that for the first time have enabled Hamas to strike as far as Tel Aviv and Jerusalem.
articles.abstract: Israel is focused on arms that for the first time have enabled Hamas to strike as far as Tel Aviv and Jerusalem.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — When Israel assassinated the top Hamas military commander in Gaza on Wednesday, setting off the current round of fierce fighting, it was aiming not just at a Palestinian leader but at a supply line of rockets from Iran that have for the first time given Hamas the ability to strike as far as Tel Aviv and Jerusalem.

articles.headline: European Countries Seek More Taxes From U.S. Multinational Companies
articles.snippet: European governments are going after American companies, like Google and Amazon.com, that pay little or no taxes in Europe, despite generating billions of dollars in revenue on the continent.
articles.abstract: European governments are going after American companies, like Google and Amazon.com, that pay little or no taxes in Europe, despite generating billions of dollars in revenue on the continent.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Google reported sales of more than $4 billion in Britain last year. It paid less than $10 million in taxes.

articles.headline: Washington Post’s Chief Falters Anew
articles.snippet: Katharine Weymouth seems to be upending the loyalty and accountability that have been a hallmark of her family’s ownership of the newspaper.
articles.abstract: Katharine Weymouth seems to be upending the loyalty and accountability that have been a hallmark of her family’s ownership of the newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: At 11:45 a.m. last Tuesday, the editorial staff of The Washington Post was summoned on short notice to an announcement on the fifth floor of its building to hear something they already knew — that Marcus Brauchli would be leaving after four years as executive editor. After Mr. Brauchli spoke, Katharine Weymouth, the newspaper’s publisher, told employees that he would be replaced by Marty Baron, the editor of The Boston Globe.

articles.headline: Guys Drive a Network on YouTube
articles.snippet: Machinima, with its game-oriented shows, trailers and news reports, is in the vanguard of video Web sites attracting young male viewers away from traditional media companies.
articles.abstract: Machinima, with its game-oriented shows, trailers and news reports, is in the vanguard of video Web sites attracting young male viewers away from traditional media companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Big Media’s hunt for young male viewers is not going so well.

articles.headline: The Tablet Market Grows Cluttered
articles.snippet: Tablets were supposed to be a simple alternative to the bloated personal computer market. But now that the iPad has strong competitors, shopping decisions are becoming harder.
articles.abstract: Tablets were supposed to be a simple alternative to the bloated personal computer market. But now that the iPad has strong competitors, shopping decisions are becoming harder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Holiday shoppers with a tablet computer on their gift list this year might be forgiven for feeling a little panicked.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Investors Rush to Beat Threat of Higher Taxes
articles.snippet: With potential changes in the tax code set to take place on Jan. 1, investors and business owners have begun to protect their income before the end of the year.
articles.abstract: With potential changes in the tax code set to take place on Jan. 1, investors and business owners have begun to protect their income before the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Business owners and investors are rapidly maneuvering to shield themselves from the prospect of higher taxes next year, a strategy that is sending ripples across Wall Street and broad areas of the economy.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: Protests Backed by Union Get Wal-Mart’s Attention
articles.snippet: Wal-Mart has filed a complaint seeking to prevent a group known as OUR Walmart from staging protests against the company on Black Friday, the busiest shopping day of the year.
articles.abstract: Wal-Mart has filed a complaint seeking to prevent a group known as OUR Walmart from staging protests against the company on Black Friday, the busiest shopping day of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Wal-Mart has fended off repeated efforts by unions and their supporters to organize its workers. Now, that battle is once again escalating.
articles.byline: By Steven Greenhouse and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Back on Hill, Ryan Remains a Fiscal Force
articles.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan has been tapped to help strike a deal to avoid big tax increases and spending cuts by the end of the year, and to bring along fellow Republicans.
articles.abstract: Representative Paul D. Ryan has been tapped to help strike a deal to avoid big tax increases and spending cuts by the end of the year, and to bring along fellow Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gone is the private jet and the motorcade that swept him from the tarmac to the private hotel entrances. His security staff has been reduced to a few Capitol Police officers, soon to fade away. Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin is back to driving his own truck back home, and walking to the House floor here for votes alone, like everyone else.

articles.headline: An Outgunned Hamas Tries to Tap Islamists’ Growing Clout
articles.snippet: As Israel and Hamas met separately with Egyptian officials for indirect talks about a truce in the ongoing Gaza fight, Hamas seemed to be trying to exert its sway over ideological allies in Egypt’s government.
articles.abstract: As Israel and Hamas met separately with Egyptian officials for indirect talks about a truce in the ongoing Gaza fight, Hamas seemed to be trying to exert its sway over ideological allies in Egypt’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Emboldened by the rising power of Islamists around the region, the Palestinian militant group Hamas demanded new Israeli concessions to its security and autonomy before it halts its rocket attacks on Israel, even as the conflict took an increasing toll on Sunday.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh

articles.headline: Brigades That Fire on Israel Are Showing a New Discipline
articles.snippet: As many as 15,000 Qassam fighters are responsible for most of the rocket blitzes that have blanketed southern Israel in recent days, experts say.
articles.abstract: As many as 15,000 Qassam fighters are responsible for most of the rocket blitzes that have blanketed southern Israel in recent days, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAGHAZI REFUGEE CAMP, Gaza Strip — From the time he was a boy, Ali al-Manama dreamed of joining the Izzedine al-Qassam Brigades, the military wing of the Islamic Hamas movement. His commitment intensified when his father, a Qassam fighter, was killed by an Israeli drone in 2001 as he fired mortar shells over the border. Ali joined up at 15, relatives said, and by 23 had risen to be a commander in this neighborhood in the midsection of this coastal Palestinian territory.

articles.headline: Intel Chief Executive to Retire in May
articles.snippet: The president and chief executive of Intel, Paul S. Otellini, is retiring in May after 40 years with the company. The company said it would prepare to transition to a new leader over the next six months.
articles.abstract: The president and chief executive of Intel, Paul S. Otellini, is retiring in May after 40 years with the company. The company said it would prepare to transition to a new leader over the next six months.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After almost 40 years at Intel, its chief executive, Paul S. Otellini, is retiring, just as the company struggles with a momentous challenge: computing’s big shift to mobile devices.
